Our group of thirteen, travelling with Flamingo Lanka, arrived at the sacred site of Sri Maha Bodhi in the afternoon on 21st November 2025.  The 500 metre walk from the designated car park was through well-kept pathways shaded by many other large trees.  Halfway to the bo tree, we reached a shoe counter where we left our shoes for safekeeping at no charge.  Continuing barefoot, we joined a stream of pilgrims, mostly dressed in white, carrying offerings of flowers and incense. The Sri Maha Bodhi is recognised as the oldest living human-planted tree in the world, having been planted in 288BC.  It originated from a cutting of the Bo tree in Bodh Gaya, India - the very tree under which Lord Buddha attained enlightenment.  The sapling was brought to Sri Lanka by Sanghamitta, a buddhist nun, and ceremoniously received by the king marking a significant moment in the island’s religious history. Over the centuries, the Sri Maha Bodhi has been continuously protected and cared for by Buddhist monks, devoted kings and now by the government.  It stands surrounded by golden railings on a high platform, serving as the spiritual heart of Anuradhapura.  For more than 2300 years, this sacred tree has been venerated by Buddhists from around the world, making it one of the most revered pilgrimage sites in Sri Lanka. Standing before the Sri Maha Bodhi, we felt a profound sense of connection to the pilgrims who had come here for centuries before us.  The experience was both humbling and inspiring – a reminder of faith and tradition.

Bodhi is called banyan in Russian. In Buddhism, this tree has sacred meaning and is found in every monastery. The high status is due to the fact that it was under it that Gautama attained enlightenment in Bodh Gaya. However, that tree did not survive, but from its seed was grown a tree in Anuradhapura in the time of King Ashoka. It is pointless to argue over the sacred status of this tree, for it is the truth of faith, not the truth of reason. But the fact that this tree has the longest documented history in the world is highly probable. 2,300 years! What's more, the sprouts of this ficus have been taken to Buddhist monasteries all over the world! True, if you look closely, you'll see that the tree is not one, but several. Besides, the oldest one won't let you in, it's upstairs behind the fence.

Sacred Sri Maha Bodhi – A Spiritual and Serene Experience Visiting Sri Maha Bodhi in Anuradhapura was a truly unforgettable and spiritual experience. As one of the oldest historically authenticated trees in the world, believed to be a sapling of the Bodhi tree under which Lord Buddha attained enlightenment, this sacred site holds immense religious and cultural significance. Atmosphere & Spiritual Significance The moment you step into the temple premises, you can feel the peaceful and sacred atmosphere. The air is filled with the scent of incense, the soft murmurs of prayers, and the sight of devoted pilgrims offering flowers and lighting oil lamps. The tree itself is beautifully adorned with golden fences and prayer flags, symbolizing its revered status. Cleanliness & Maintenance The temple grounds are well-maintained, clean, and organized, ensuring a comfortable experience for visitors. The surrounding gardens and pathways are serene, providing a perfect space for quiet reflection and meditation. Best Time to Visit Early mornings or late evenings are the best times to visit, as the weather is cooler, and the ambiance is even more peaceful. During poya (full moon) days, the temple sees a larger number of devotees, making it a deeply spiritual and lively experience. Visitor Tips Dress modestly, covering shoulders and knees, as it is a sacred Buddhist site. Bring an offering, such as flowers, oil lamps, or incense, to participate in rituals. Remove footwear before entering the temple premises. Respect the silence and spiritual environment. Overall Experience ⭐ 5/5 – A must-visit for anyone traveling to Sri Lanka, whether for religious, cultural, or historical interest. The tranquility, devotion, and centuries-old history make Sri Maha Bodhi a truly remarkable destination.

column11: Jayasrimaha Bhodiya Anuradapura is an awe-inspiring sacred site in Sri Lanka, renowned for its deep historical and religious significance. This remarkable location is home to the oldest recorded living tree planted by humans, believed to be a direct descendant of the very tree under which the Buddha achieved enlightenment. Pilgrims from every corner of the globe flock to this hallowed ground to offer their respects and seek divine blessings. The tranquil and serene ambiance of Jayasrimaha Bhodiya Anuradapura creates the perfect setting for meditation and introspection. Its profound cultural heritage and breathtaking architectural wonders make it an absolute must-visit for anyone eager to delve into the rich history and spirituality of Sri Lanka. Sinse history all the Sri Lankan Kings have elevated the status of this sacred site, surrounding it with a magnificent golden fence and supporting its branches with golden scaffolding, underscoring the immense importance of this tree to Buddhist devotees. The sheer grandeur and reverence bestowed upon Jayasrimaha Bhodiya Anuradapura serve as a testament to its unparalleled significance in the hearts of all who visit.

According to History Indian emperor Asoka dispatched his daughter-nun Theri Sanghamitta to Lanka with a sapling of the sacred Bodhi obtained from the main stem of the bodhi tree in Bodh Gaya where Buddha attained enlightenment.  In Sri Lanka, King Tissa received the sapling and planted it in his garden at the present site in 249 BC. This makes this tree 2266 years old (in 2016). This tree is  considered the oldest living tree in the world in the recorded history. People who live in the neighbourhood, whose ancestors received land for their services are still the guardians of the tree in addition to the buddhist priests.  This age-old custom of guarding continues to date. In 1985 the LTTE terrorists attacked these premises killing over 170 priests, men, women and children.  The tree escaped unharmed. Note:  Foreigners need a day ticket (Approx 16USD) from Department of Museums that allows them free access to all cultural sites in and around Anuradhapura.  No foot wear allowed within the premises.  Visitors are requested to be dressed in simple covered clothing appropriate for a religious location. Jaya Sri Maha Bodhi is the most sacred place in Anuradhapura. It is a raised platform in Mahameghawana Gardens which contains a branch of a fig tree (called Maha Bodhi in Buddhism) under which Mahatma Buddha is stated to have attained enlightenment (nirwan) in Buddha Gaya, India. This tree (sapling) was planted here in 249 BC and is known as the oldest surviving tree in the world which has a known date of plantation. It was brought here by Sangamitta, daughter of Emperor Ashoka of India with great pomp and show 2500 years ago. Emperor Ashoka was himself present in the celebrations held at the Indian port of Tamalitta in which this sapling was dispatched to Sri Lanka in a ship. Sri Lankan King Devanam Piyatissa himself received the sapling at the Sri Lankan port with great honor and pageantry. While standing under this tree, I thought that it was like a ‘peepel’ tree. For about two billion people of the world, it is the most sacred tree and is called “Roots of Paradise on Earth” by Buddhists.

I'd rather go see the original in Bodhgaya. For devotees only.

We stopped as part of a full day out on bikes but this is somewhere you should see. It was an amazing experience to witness the importance of the temple for the locals. The whole place has an atmosphere of hushed reverence.

Such a beautiful site, the Bodhi tree also neighbors other attractions seen in Anuradhapura such as Lovamahapaya ( the stone ruin pillars ) and Ruwanwelisseya Dagoba ( the large white building that normally represents the main attraction in Anuradhapura ) Our day was simply amazing due to one key factor, our Tuk Tuk driver "Lalith Priyashantha" This kind man is the only reason I have started my trip adviser account so I could blog about his services to us. We arrived at 9:05am and only had until 3:30pm ,all other drivers only offered to drive us to each site. He took us around like we were family and explained his culture and the Buddhist religion, history and meanings behind every single detail at each location. He made us feel safe, welcomed and very comfortable. As we only had a short time we needed a place to store our bags so he called his shop owner friends and organized everything for us. Here comes the crescendo, he wanted to do it all for only $15 AUD which is 1500 rupees . A FULL 6 hours of driving us:  to get food ,storing our bags and even including the prices for the attractions we viewed for well over half the going price of everyone else ( $40aud for a tour guide ) he knew EVERYTHING about each site, down to the year it was made, who made it the history and the stories behind everything, he cared about us learning his culture. We could not have asked for a better 6 hours in this beautiful ancient city. By the end of it my girlfriend and I were so happy with his service we gave him $30 AUD because how special he made the day, he WOULDN'T EVEN ACCEPT THE MONEY !! He asked us if we were students, we told him we weren't and that we had full time jobs just so he'd take the offer. His contact numbers are : +94 777 951719 +94 7111 24601 +94 768502504 You can also contact him on Facebook via his name above Feel free to contact me for any information about the day :)
The oldest historically documented tree on earth were Buddha gained enlightenment. Very sacred and serene place to visit

column7: Capelle aan den IJssel, The Netherlands
column11: The bodhi tree is not very interesting only with the story that this tree is very old makes it worthwhile to seen.

By all means visit Sri Lanka. It is a special place with all its charm. But none of these World Heritage sites worth visiting. Not a single one of these ancient cities can qualify to be sites worth seeing. Go visit Tikal, Cairo, Varanasi, Chaco, Angkor, and the list goes on. This tree is a hype as well. Pay a lot of money to walk on barefoot to see sapling behind a fence.

It’s say that this ancient tree is grown out of a root/branch of the original Bodhi tree in India. The hundreds of pilgrims make this spiritual place very special. It was amazing to see the pilgrims praying, offering gift and worship this place. The tree is surrounded by a fence so you can’t see the tree very well. If you want to make an offer to the tree, you need to give your gifts to the guards. They put them under the tree. You experience the Buddism very well.
Can't avoid feeling the spirit of this (oldest?) tree on earth, grown from a cutting of the Bo tree Siddhartha meditated under when he became Enlightened. Truly amazing.

If you are not a buddhist the tree does not have any meening to you and from that standpoint isn't overly exciting to see. What's making this whole thing interesting is seeing all the people and what they are doing there. We were there on one of the holy days, so it got pretty crowded. There were lots of offerings and people everywhere. We felt a bit like intruders disturbing the rituals, but our guide told us it would be o.k. to walk around and take pictures there. I hope that was not only him. ;-)
Said to be grown from a sapling brought from the Bodhi tree from Gaya below which Buddha is supposed to have attained entitlement. A bit of a walk from the Ruwanwelisaya stupa.

The sacred Bo Tree, stemming from the original Bo Tree Buddha found enlightenment under, is an impressive structure surrounded by several small temples and prayer rooms. The site draws pilgrims from all of Sri Lanka to regularly pray and pay tribute. Quite an experience not to be missed when in the area. The sand covered grounds are a relief for your bare feet.
Not much really to add to the title really.  Devotees of Buddah would find this of interest as would other tourists.
It was very busy the day we visited but it was worth the hustle and bustle. We had a priest tie our wrists and say a blessing for us which was very special.
If you are religious and into Buddhism then this is a very important site. Its a popular site for Buddhists but if you are tight on schedule and have limited time in Anuradhapura, you can miss it.

It is always difficult to be a tourist at someone else's religious site, and this place is a very significant centre for Buddhists. Whilst there were literally hundreds of people sitting around the perimeter, or quietly walking ( always clockwise), around the shrine, and a constant burble of chanting, it was a peaceful and humbling experience, and a privilege to be allowed to be there.

We found that there was not a lot of information about the site that was obvious when we visited. Central area was locked off. Nice enough, but without the info, a little mysterious. Yes I know we could have done a bit of research, but some on site information would be good.

I'm not a Buddhist, but the site was moving nonetheless. I really enjoyed the serenity of the temple and it was interesting to watch people worship. The Bodhi tree itself was a bit lackluster, but still an interesting piece of history.

Incredibly moving site. The temple has a feeling of peace and serenity. Remember to take socks as the ground is baking hot and as you have to leave your shoes outside you can end up with burnt feet. Also as all sacred sites and temples you have to have your upper legs and shoulders covered.

Word of Advice: Do not wear any clothing with Lord Buddha on it, it is offensive to locals. Also, your apparel should cover your knees. (shorts etc. may not be advisable) Anuradhapura is a great place to know about Buddhism from close quarters. Must visit are the stupas near the Bodhi tree. Do spend some time at the Stupa watching people pray. It is a great feeling.

Supposedly the longest living tree in the world at over 2500 years of age.  But only a small trunk with a long off-shoot of the original tree survives.  But the ambience is steeped in faith and devotion.

I arrived at 6am to offer flowers to the Bodhi tree. The atmosphere was so good early morning. Flowers are available at the other side of the temple. Do wear decently - long white trouser and skirt. White top covering the shoulders too.
We went to visit the tree but enjoyed being able to take time absorbing the culture and atmosphere of this special place.

Oldest Bo Tree in the country that worship by all the Buddhist around world. It says this is a child plant of Bodhi that uses lord buddha to be the greatest person of the world. This tree got a written history of more than 2000 years and Sri Lankan Buddhists have protect this from all the invaders they got. Very relaxing place to be. Better to visit on morning or evening. Avoid fullmoon poya days as much as you can.

So glad we found time to visit - Sri Maya Bodhi is beautiful and the hundreds of people, pilgrims and monks make this a special place, regardless of your faith. Good to visit in the evening when cooler and the light is better
A most for any one seeking to learn some basics about the spread of Buddism. A magical setting and story. This site is the highlight of the city.
It was very humbling to be in a place which housed a sapling from the Bodhi tree under which Buddha sat and attained enlightenment. To boot, it is located in lovely ancient Anuradhapura grounds.
Definitely worth a visit as part of the Anuradhapura city tour. You get access to many places of which this one. Macaques are running around so keep your belongings close :)

It was a very informative trip for kids, my self and my wife got endless questions ,Concerns and suggestions frommy kids about each and every places that we visited. (many times I have to shout at them to keep quite for a 5 mins) Still they do have very valid but unanswerable questions which I have to google and find-out.

Sri Lanka recieved Buddhism in 3rd century BC . Arhat Mahinda thero appeared on rock of Mihintale ( Anuradhapura ) and met King Devanampiyatissa and introduce Buddhism to Sri Lanka . After few years back Arhat Mahinda s sister came to Sri Lanka with plant of Bo Tree ( ficus religiosa ) which gave shelter for Buddha during enlightment . That Bo tree planted in Anuradhapura and worshiped by Buddhist for centuries . Arhat Mahinda and Nun Sangamitta is the Son and Daughter of Great Emperor Ashoka of India .
It is huge tree, but it behind the gates. The guards take gifts from the people and put them under the tree.

Enjoyed a quick visit here on a recent trip to Anuradhapura. Skipped paying by coming in the side entrance (good if you didn't buy the $25 pass), no shoes, so be aware of your own needs. Ground gets a little hot and rocky. If you are not there for religious reasons, be aware of those that are. Do not walk in front of people praying,  don't take pictures of people without asking (especially monks) and just be quiet as you walk around. Definitely a powerful feeling while visiting.

I went at dusk, and the atmosphere was wonderfully serene, despite the number of people worshipping, watching and walking around. Even if you're not a believer, this feels like a place of great import. Go and allow yourself to be part of it; you'll feel the good Buddhist vibes.
When we visited the site it was very crowded by praying people. Tourist information were very scarce. Nobody asked for the tickets. There is no place for a good view of the tree.

This is a place of devotion and prayer. It is like walking into a church in Europe in the middle of a service except that you are most welcome. Enter with respect for the locals and treat the site as what it is: a place a spiritual significance for locals not a tourist attraction. Enjoy the colors, sounds and energy of the place and you should walk away smiling.
Perhaps it was the day and time we came but it was crazy busy. A lot of people all the time. The tree itself was impressive for its size and age.

... however it was interesting to see how much it mattered to the Buddhists there. We visited here as part of a tour of Anuradhapura given to us by a guide. We visited here last on our tour as it was getting dark. It was actually a nice to see it as dusk gave the whole place a mystical feeling. You'll need to make sure you cover your upper arms and knees to be allowed in. They are very strict on this.

The trip to Anuradhapur was just by chance as we had to exchange some money while on our trip to Wilpattu. The sacred city of Anuradhapura is one of the oldest continuously inhabited cities in the world and was the ancient capital. The first thing to visit which came on our mind was to visit the Bodhi Tree which was brought from India by the daughter of Ashoka, the great, Sanghamitra, was planted at a very auspicious location in the city. This world heritage and religious site was such awe inspiring to visit though we didnt have much time and daylight it was such a 'yog' to visit the Bodhi tree and be blessed by it - it made our Wilpattu and Srilanka trip such a success !!
located in anuradapura sri lanka. its most important site for all the world budist people. why before 2500 years loard buddha enter the enlighterment under the this tree.

I recommend to see this place (including the whole Anuradhapura) when Sri Lankan celebrate their New Year. The feast takes a week and during this time many Sri Lankan families from the whole country go to Bodhi Tree (and other sacred places) to bring sacrifices (flowers, food) and to pray. You hardly see any tourists.

We biked around Anuradhapura for the afternoon, which was a great way to see the sites, and while there was no sunset that day, we arrived at the Bodhi Tree as musicians lead a crowd carrying a 100m long multi coloured "ribbon" that was delivered to the monks who then wrapped it around the fence of the tree, with increasing chanting by the crowd. This was a moving and beautiful ceremony that really made our day, which had been long and hot and a bit tiring. I'm not sure if this happens every Saturday or if it was a special occasion, but if you're there - check it out!
It is nice to see how the Sri Lankans honor and worship this holy place. The Bo tree is the centre of the complex.Hundreds of people from all over the country come here to pray and offer flowers.
To us this was just a very large old tree supported and surrounded with gold plated posts.  It is hard to believe this tree is over 2000 years old.

Please wear white and wear something full length when you go there as a mark of respect. But it is not compulsory. It is quite a nice place and is quite active there. Was good to see people so engrossed in their activities. Also do not forget to visit the Stupa which is near it!

This place is full of people dressed in white, nuns and monks saying their prayers. Very special to observe. You can buy Sri Lankas national flower outside (water lily) and offer it inside of one of the small temples around the tree. I liked all the flags surrounding the pavilion and the tree, they cast very nice shadows. Beautiful place. Bring socks, the sand burns your foot soles!
We have seen the Bodhi Tree in Bodh Gaya in India which we liked a lot better. This version is very small and as spiritual as we expected it.

The Bodhi tree is more than 2600 years old. It was a very special trip for me as I am a Buddhist.  I felt so peaceful and felt like I was giving respect and pray to Buddha, himself. If you could, please visit early in the morning and late evening to avoid the heat.
Full of pilgrims reciting prayers and offering flowers wonderful to watch. Ground gets very hot, socks essential
This tree is reputed to be one of the oldest in Sri-Lanka and important to Buddhists. It is surrounded by fences to protect it (unsderstandably) and difficult to photograph.
When we arrived, it was closed until 2pm. Be aware of this fact and plan accordingly. If you walk around, you can still have a good view of the tree.
Sacred of all trees. It takes as living Buddha. So very holy and respectable place. Please keep silence in all time.

I only wish we could see the whole trunk of the tree! The only part that is visible is the top of the tree as it rises above the temple. The base of it is in the area that is off limits. It doesn't look as old as they say it is, but then again it is very well looked after.
Not as good as Lumbini, but very nice overall.  Just remember to wear socks if you can't handle the heat of the stones.

The Bo Tree of Lord Buddha, is the oldest registered tree in the world and more than 2000 year's old. Feel the history when you are under it. Be early in the morning so that you can still find a few original leafes from the tree if you want to take a real relic home.
It was interesting because it is supposed to be a start from the tree where Buddha obtained enlightnent, but total lame as to appearance

This kind of thing is personal to say the least. I liked that they didn't charge the morning we went, and I found the monkeys there more fascinating than the tree. Now, don't get me wrong ... I like really old sacred trees, and have seen a few in my travels, but this Bodhi tree didn't touch me in any special way, and I was left unmoved. But, if you're in town, you might as well swing by and see if it touches you in any way.
this is supposed to be the oldest surviving tree in the woprld. the original tree of this was supposed to have given shade to lord buddha when he attained enlightenment.

I don't know what I was expecting when I was informed I would get to see a tree grown from the sampling of the tree Buddha gained enlightenment under, but all I can say is that I was surprise.  The tree spans out over the top of this platform and is held up in spots by golden supports.  Worshipers at the temple vie for the caretaker's attention in order to ask for leaves from the tree.  It was quite the sight to see.

Anyone interested in Buddhism or the general culture of Sri Lanka must become associated with the Bodhi or Bo tree. This was the tree beneath which it is believed that the Buddha reached Enlightenment. A branch from the tree was brought to Sri Lanka and planted here in the third century BC. The Anuradhapura Bodhi tree is of particular importance for its history and sacred association yet one can find Bo trees in Temple areas throughout the country which are held in the highest reverence and respect.

We visited it in Anuradhapura. It is the sacred tree of Buddha. The first branch was brought from the tree where Buddha used to rest. There is also a statue of the woman who brought the branch to Sri Lanka.

Not just one of the very important monument of the Sri Lankan early kingdoms and buddhism history! It's a really living sacred place now. The world's oldest documented tree, under which Buddha meditated and enlightened. One branch of this tree in 288 BC was brought from India by Sangamitta - the daughter of King Asoka. Don't forget, hat and shoes forbidden inside the sacred area. You will need sun protection cream, and exchange socks is very practical. The reason not just the dirty floor (these places wasn't really dirty), very often the stone very hot without shoes. I recommend you, before the visit you must read some historical fact about this place, will be interesting the visit!
Different religions and nations find this place good for pray, me too, I was impressed by all this people around me. It was cleaner than in any other place

A nice long walk from the Milano guesthoose if you are feeling fit catch a Tuk Tuk back for 200rp, a must go for the age of the tree and an attraction to the Sri Lankan populace. Beautiful flower offerings to buy and don't forget no shots bring a sarong as that will suffice, well worth a visit.
Great sense of culture, it f"eels" special and significant. Watch out for the people as you go in trying to give you a flower. If you take one, you'll regret it on the way out!!!!

Although this Bodhi tree is very old I think the visit to this site is interesting from a religious or cultural perspective, as opposed to a historical one. The site is actively used by Sri Lankan Buddhists for prayer giving non religios visitors the opportunity to observe Buddhist ritual first hand.
As a person who is not very religious, the power of the chanting was haunting, similar to being caught in a wave. Try to visit during the full moon

In SriLanka, a Buddhist religious country, people worship this tree as a sacred place. This tree is a sapling from the historical Bodhi tree, where Buddha enlightened. It was planted here in 288 BC and is the oldest living human planted tree in the world. (But the oldest living tree is in California USA, is 5064 years old). The tree is surrounded by thick walls, on top of that golden fence also there. Just for anyone it's an ancient tree surrounded by historical statues, walls etc, but for Buddhists this place is a very holy site. My personal opinion if I visit a place for the ancient value, I have to see the place on my own way, not distracted by other people. Already I traveled all over the world, and visited most of the ancient monuments. But here religious value distracted the real ancient value. I am disappointed.

Bodhi Tree - the seat of Vajrashan which provided the shelter to Siddharth Gautam to rise as the Lord Buddha. The most defining tree which historically changed and alter the pace of time and crossed horizons and boundaries of class, caste, creed, culture, race and regions. The tree is magnificent, its persona is symbolic to wisdom-hood. Mere looking at it takes you to millennia at a time when it must only have been a tree, just another tree in the forests of Gaya sheltering thousands of sadhus and monks who were searching of knowledge, enlightenment and peace. With Rahul and Sanghmtra sent by Emperor Ashok himself, who planted the tree at the present site of Anuradhapura is frequently visited place in Sri Lanka. It holds immense importance as it provides the unbroken chain with the original tree of Gaya that was burnt during the 7th century A.D. I have found the site very peaceful and will encourage tourists and pilgrims to visit at the right time and it is one of the most revered and holiest of the sites.

The symbolism of this place is the attraction, as well as the feeling of peace around it. The story goes that the old tree is a direct descendant of the bodhi tree under which the Buddha found enlightenment. Don't forget to pack a pair of old socks because you have to take off your shoes, and the ground is hot.

I rolled in by train to Anuradhapura around 10AM-a little behind schedule-but with plenty of time to see the Bodhi Tree. I was a little disappointed to discover the tree was only viewable from a distance, behind a locked gate.  TIP: No one tells you this, but they open it up after 2pm daily for visitors to get a closer look.  Regardless, while there, I stumbled upon a prayer session and there were these school kids on a field trip there to take part.  It was really lovely to see. I walked around barefoot, took some photos. It really was my first intro to Sri Lanka, so yeah, I guess it was seeing an sacred tree was an alright way to begin.

This is a very holy site for Buddhists and most Sri Lankans and the ambience around the tree and the buildings is very peaceful and relaxing.  While you cannot get close to the tree itself you can view the canopy and enjoy the calm.

This sacred tree, grown from a sapling of the original Bodhi Tree in Bodhgaya India and brought here by Asoka's daughter Sanghamitta in the 3rd century BC, is of enormous significance to Buddhists from all over the world.  This is a central and very sacred place of pilgrimage and the atmosphere is very special, especially so during daily puja's and poya days. Namo Buddhaya, Budu Saranai, Theruwan Saranai. May all beings be happy and well.

As others have said, it's just a tree - but it is a hugely important and sacred one if you are a Buddhist. The amount of care and attention that it has received over the centuries has been remarkable, and all carefully recorded too. It's also worth a visit even if you're not a Buddhist. However, as others have also said, the extra charge for entry is unnecessary. The Sri Lankan National sport of relieving overseas tourists of their money does get extremely wearing after a while. It's like having someone's fingers perpetually in your wallet. Apparently, there used to be a single payment that got you in to all the ancient sites, but that was discontinued and now each site gets to make it's own charges. Hmmmm. Quite a backward step, I think.

When you hear 2,000 year old tree, or the oldest tree in the world you think of something amazing. Think again. It's a normal looking tree and you can barely see it anyway as it has a wall around it. Useless you're a Buddhist or history buff, don't bother. To make it worse the security guard said I couldn't enter in shorts (I'm male), what a load of rubbish, first time ever that's happened in all the religious Temples and areas I've been to. Of course there were sorongs conveniently located nearby for a small fee, not expensive at all, but I get the feeling I am opening my wallet to every Sri Lankan that walks past me and it weighs you down. The entire city is a scam and it makes me angry that I handed my money over. The highlight of my time was seeing some stray puppies and a kitten, that's saying something.

The branch of bo tree was brought here some 2,300 years ago directly from India by Sanghamitta thero, daughter of Emperor Ashoka.  Although the tree was not very large or bushy in appearance, it has its spiritual value.  As such many worshipers came and made their blessings and offerings and the whole area appeared to be peaceful but lively.  Worshipers could have their lunch in the surrounding area after the pilgrimage visit.

This is a very important place in Sri Lanka specially for the Buddhist people. This is a branch of real Bo tree from India which Lord Buddha was enlightened. This was brought to Sri Lanka by Saṅghamittā thero who was the daughter of Emperor Ashoka in India. Where well covered cloths if you wish to visit this place.

The tree itself was a big disappointment; it was neither enormously big, nor specially beautiful. You easily see nicest ones all around the country. I do agree though that the ambience is pretty mystical and the site is "alive". By the way don't expect to approach the tree too close: there is a wall around it, apparently to avoid illnesses and make a follow up on its health. One thing that I find annoying is that there is a separate, extra payment for the tree: really?! We just paid 25 dollars to the Government (NOT the people or the site, if you listen to the locals)
Religious site so you have to be aware of your clothing and be prepared to go barefoot. Here it is not good to stress better to adapt the speed of walking to the other visitors. Peaceful atmosphere.
Despite the 2000 year old tree being a fair bit smaller than we expected, the area is quite magical, it would be a perfect spot for some meditation when it's not too busy,.

This is apparently the oldest tree recorded in history (2,300 years old) - the level of devotion and love shown to the tree and the Buddha it represents, is wonderful to see.  A real live Buddhist venue, with non-tourist activities going on.  Peaceful, happy and beautiful place. The tree is surrounded by a structure to keep people away, a bit disappointing but it makes the whole place more appealing.

The Sri Lankans claim this buddhist bodhi tree is the oldest tree in the world. It is certainly sacred and the site of religious pilgrimage for Buddhists.  Tourists should go quietly and respectfully.  You will also notice extensive security the result of Tamil attacks in the 90's.
Came here thinking that. It's actually the oldest and living human-planted tree in the world. The tree looks old no doubt but it looks like any other Bo tree you can find in Sri Lanka.

We saw the tree on a day where many pilgrims were there offering gifts of thanks. There were a number of monks and nuns and people praying all around. It was a very special and spiritual experience, because of the worshipping crowds

I'm not religious at all (except for the Flying Spaghetti Monster, look it up trust me) but there is something special about this place. Groups of monks on pilgrimages praying in unison might have something to it but I had goose bumps the whole time I was here.
This tree is really old. There are much newer and younger trees all around the local area. If you like really old things go to this, but it is seriously old so don't go if you like newer trees.
Whenever I visit Anuradhapura, I always make it a point to visit this holy site. It can be very crowded but the mere sight of this sacred tree can have a calming effect on people

Most scared tree for Buddhists . Always full of pilgrims. Why I am not rating this place as excellent is that it is not preserved in its original form of archeological value. Place look more modern than it's heritage of 2000+ years.

I loved this place so much. We went first thing in the morning right when it opened. Observing the pilgrims making offerings, praying and meditating before those beautiful bodhi trees was a wonderful and awe-inspiring sight. It is a busy spot but so peaceful. Definitely worth the trip!

Visited as part of our day tour of Anuradhapura city. No fee for tourists but 25 rupees for leaving our shoes (a tiny sum of money which I do not resent) and we were too gullible to avoid buying flowers to offer to the Buddha but this is clearly a holy site for practising Buddhists and we were happy to leave flowers. We were reminded by our guide to avoid being photographed with our backsides to Buddha as this is considered  to be offensive but Buddhist worshippers were happy to photograph us with a side on view. Difficult to see much of  the Bodhi tree but glad we visited.

Ancient city is amazing,  $25 entry. Can get a tuc tuc anywhere in the new town and do the ancient city in a couple of hours or much cheaper way is to rent a bicycle for the day. It took me almost a whole day to see all the sites in old the city by bicycle ask your hotel for a map. I stayed in Melbourne Hotel, cheap, nice, they have bicycles, see review on Melbourne Hotel. List and brief review of the sights I went to in The Ancient city: Bodhi Tree Temple (The Sri Maha Bodhiya), this was the main thing I wanted to see, bit dissapointing, you can not get close to the tree, big wall around it. it is not possible to drive up to the temple, and one must go through a metal detector before entering the complex. Shoes can be left near the entrance. It is polite to leave a tip. Ruwanwelisaya: the oldest and most largest stupa at Anuradhapura, has , been fully restored, painted white, and is currently a centre of worship. The Archaeolgy Museum, interesting, ask at the entrance for a museum guide, it is free. Showcases many of the artifacts found at the site The Folk Museum: Showcases the archaeology of Anuradhapura from a more folk perspective. Jetavana: Large stupa The Citadel: This was the secular centre of the city. The Moonstone. This moonstone is of particular note, for its size and impressive decoration.

This is the known oldest tree of religious value in the whole world & worshipped by many people from all over the world, its of immense religious value to Buddhists. The temple & the surrounding areas are very clean & well kept since my last visit, which is a pleasure. Please be aware f the monkeys for people who have not visited this place before, also to be appropriately dressed, better in covered white clothes as a a respect to this great religion. A must visit for all Buddhists in the world.

Standardized huts for the vendors. Canopy for the pathway connecting Ruwamali Saya and The Sacred Bo Tree. Battery operated vehicles for the sights to minimize the Damage to the sacred bo tree etc...caused by vehicle emission.

As a Buddhist doing a pilgrimage trip this was a very special place to visit, made even better by the fact that it is the only place in Sri Lanka where tourists are not charged anything to get in. A very serene place and a great place to sit and reflect.

The tree is kept elevated and guarded, so all you can see from down below is just a few branches with no indication of how huge it really is. But the temple on the ground is a real Buddhist temple, and you can see people praying, chanting and meditating. Overall, not a bad site, but perhaps not the most exciting one to see.

Even though I am not a Buddhist, I could sense the "sacredness" of the place. The original Bo tree is now just a thin remnant (almost like a branch). We went on a Sunday, and the temple was quite crowded with pilgrims dressed in white. Perhaps you can avoid Sundays to have a more peaceful visit. I would also recommend using the guide - Asoka - who gave us an excellent introduction and crash course to Buddhism and the Bo tree (perhaps one of the reasons why we enjoyed visiting this Tree). Asoka can be reached at +94 718907081.

I have seen many sacred places in Sri Lanka, so this time I just wanted to see "The Tree" but there are just buildings around so you can only see branch or two. People pray at metal construction supporting the branch...truly spiritual...
The place was good and neatly maintained. But you need to walk for quite a distance on barefoot with the sun beating down.

To experience the immensity, history and beauty of this complex of temples, palaces and museums, one may want to fortify themselves and plan to tour for a good part of a day.  We visited on a Sunday during which multitudes of pilgrims dressed in white were bringing flowers and offerings to the ancient temple Mahavihara, the site of the Sacred Bo Tree.  Here is a good place to sit or pause to absorb the spiritual meaning of this site for the Sri Lankan people.  After visiting here, my guide led me to the following main sites within this complex:  Ruvansalisaya Dogoba, Jetavana Museum, Jetavana Dagoba, LUNCH (outside of the complex), Lankarama Abhayagir Dogoba and the Twin Ponds (aka Kuttam Pokuna).  To cover this large area you will need a car/tuk tuk or marathon stamina to go on foot.  In the end, this visit was a 5 star experience.
spiritual place u dont want to miss when u here in Sri Lanka.. i had an amaizing experience at this place.. my mind was so much at peace as soon as i entered the courtyad of this temple..

The atmosphere and building makes this place more interesting as the tree it self. You have to go barefooted on sand and gravel and after so many temples my feet were becoming painful. There is a place where you can leave your shoes guarded.
A fascinating place to go and see the Bo tree and watch Sri Lankan people worship. The flowers and offerings are certainly worth a visit!

Fascinating opportunity to observe devout Buddhists - citizens and monks - come together and pray. Try to get there in the morning for the monk's procession and breakfast ritual.  Visit The Heaven and ask to hold a pink lotus flower.

I made an 8-day-trip to Sri Lanka from 8/11/12 to 15/11/12.  On my seventh day in Sri Lanka,  I arrived at the Anuradhapura Railway station at 4.30am.  Earlier, on my sixth day in Sri Lanka,i.e. 13/11/2012, I had boarded a 4.30pm-train from Hatton railway station to Colombo Fort Raiway station. Upon reaching Colombo at 10pm, I hopped into the 10.30pm train to the north of Colombo and reached Anuradhapura, one of the ancient capitals of Sri Lanka which is famous for its well-preserved ruins of ancient Sri Lankan civilization, at 4.30am, i.e. after a 12-hours-train-journey from Hatton. Anuradhapura is one of the ancient capitals of Sri Lanka, world famous for its well preserved ruins of the Great Sri Lankan Civilization. The Civilization which was built upon this city was one of the greatest civilizations of Asia and in the world. The city is now a UNESCO heritage site.  Today this ancient city of Sri Lanka, which is sacred to the Buddhist world, and which its surrounding monasteries covers an area of over sixteen square miles ( 40 km²) and is one of the world's major archaeological sites. After a morning quick tour of the Ancient Ruins & Holy City of Anuradhapura, including Thuparamaya where the collarbone of Buddha is enshrined, Isurumuniya(a picturesque rock temple) and The Sacred Jaya Siri Maha Bodhi at Mahaviharaya/ Mahameghavana Park which is recorded as the oldest surviving historical tree in the world, I took a bus back to Colombo from Anuradhapura New Town at 1pm. The oldest surviving tree in the world, The Sacred Jaya Siri Maha Bodhi at Mahaviharaya/ Mahameghavana Park, Anuradhapura, Sri Lanka, is believed to have been propagated from the original Bodhi tree.  This original Bodhi Tree, also known as Bo (from the Sinhalese Bo), was a large and very old Sacred Fig tree (Ficus religiosa) located in Bodh Gaya (about 100 km (62 mi) from Patna in the Indian state of Bihar), under which Siddhartha Gautama, the spiritual teacher later known as Gautama Buddha, is said to have achieved enlightenment, or Bodhi.  According to Buddhist texts the Buddha, after his Enlightenment, spent a whole week in front of the tree, standing with unblinking eyes, gazing at it with gratitude.  The term "Bodhi Tree" is also widely applied to currently existing trees, including the Bodhi tree in Anuradhapura, Sri Lanka, which has a great significance in the history of Buddhism. This Bodhi tree in Anuradhapura is widely mentioned in Mahavamsa.  While not considered a canonical religious text, the Mahavamsa is an important text in Theravada Buddhism. It covers the early history of religion in Sri Lanka, beginning with the time of Siddhartha Gautama, the founder of Buddhism.  According to the Mahavamsa, the Sri Maha Bodhi in Sri Lanka was planted in 288 BC, making it the oldest verified specimen of any angiosperm. In this year (the twelfth year of King Asoka's reign) the right branch of the Bodhi tree was brought by Sanghamittā to Anurādhapura and placed by Devānāmpiyatissa his left foot in the Mahāmeghavana. The Buddha, on his death bed, had resolved five things, one being that the branch which should be taken to Ceylon should detach itself. From Gayā, the branch was taken to Pātaliputta, thence to Tāmalittī, where it was placed in a ship and taken to Jambukola, across the sea; finally it arrived at Anuradhapura, staying on the way at Tivakka. Those who assisted the king at the ceremony of the planting of the Tree were the nobles of Kājaragāma and of Candanagāma and of Tivakka.  According to the Mahavamsa, branches from the Bodhi trees of all the Buddhas born during this kalpa were planted in Ceylon (Sri Lanka) on the spot where the sacred Bodhi tree stands today in Anurādhapura. Later, after completing my visit to the other attractions of the Ancient Ruins & Holy City of Anuradhapura I took a bus back to Colombo from Anuradhapura New Town at 1pm and reached the Pettah bus station in Colombo at 8pm to put-up a night at a nearby low cost lodge, i.e. Classic Inn in Panchikawatte Road before leaving for the Bandaranaike Airport at 6am of 15/11 to catch the 12.55pm flight back to Malaysia.

Local people pay homage, foreigners are curious, there are touts, as there are on most important religious centres. Perhaps not everything is as perfect as Westerns would like to see - but if you just sit down, disregard touts and monkeys as well as your own prejudices, then this is a very special place. Try to go early in the morning or late in the evening.

This is an extremely picturesque area.  The Bo Tree is only one small part of the area. The tree is extremely sacred and this site is very different to most buddhist temples in Sri Lanka, as it is very strict on clothes and shoes.

Considering its religious significance, the bodhi tree is truly underwhelming, After a long barefoot walk past some nondescript ruins, a magnificent dagoba, and some very entertaining troops of monkeys, you arrive at an enclosure surrounding an inner wall with a nondescript tree sticking out. There's quite a lot of praying going on, but no spectacular ceremonies while we were there. It's mildly interesting, but given the many truly remarkable Buddhist sites in Asia, it doesn't rank in the top 20 for visitor interest or impressiveness.

Let me create a laundry list of pros and cons explaining my poor rating: Pros: + The surrounding park area is nice and relatively peaceful, filled with monkeys and chirping birds. Cons: - Touts, touts, touts.  As is endemic throughout Sri Lanka, you find yourself having to stave off wannabe tour guides, and overly aggressive "park attendants".  There was a place left to deposit shoes before entering the holy site, with no sign mentioning a fee.  Within seconds of leaving, I was aggressively hounded for a full 5 minutes by a tout demanding a ridiculous "donation" or "fee" for leaving my shoes outside.  When I politely declined, he left for a moment, then returned to demand a 100 rupee note.  I politely explained that I had paid thousands of rupees to enter the park and grounds (itself an exorbitant 3125 rupees) and that I wasn't in the mood to deposit 100 rupee notes in each and every site I visited, or to every tout who crossed my path - I would have easily been short another 2000 rupees for that day alone.  I ended up, perhaps immaturely, offering a small handful of 2 rupee coins.  He eventually backed off.  This collection of experiences ruined what should have otherwise been a peaceful visit.
Its very Peaceful place in the morning by 10.30am it gets really croweded.you may lose were you are even.but it was nice expence all in all

Venerated by Buddhist as a sapling of the tree under which the Lord Buddha achieved enlightenment. Arguably the oldest historical tree in the world, a huge spreading Bo tree (ficus religosa) A place of veneration, contemplation, very scenic and restful surroundings, within the Anuradhapura historical city, Please remember to be clothed appropriately. Visiting during full moon nights especially memorable given the religious observances, especially during the month of Poson Poya. A must visit in Anuradhapira note: you may have to walk a fair distance, some stairs to contend with as well. Nothing extreme but to be noted

The problem is that saplings from the Bodhi tree have been planted across the world. So ever Buddhist shrine has a Bodhi tree. What you need to ask for is the Maha Bodhi tree, the big one, the original one. You can't really see the tree as it is enclosed by barriers and structures. I went on a Monday about 4 days before the Buddhist new year for Sinhalese and there was a huge crowd there. But, given my experience of crowds in Indian temples, this was a very peaceful and well mannered crowd.
Take an umbrella to sheld your head from the blazing sun
went on a sunday and the place was full of worshippers.  it was nice and interesting to watch
this is very special site for Sri Lankan Buddhist.  However, it will look like another ordinary temple for rest of the tourist.

After a 5 minute walk you can see the branch of the Bo Tree that was brought here to Sri Lanka by Indian Merchants and it is supposed to be the tree where the lord Buddha meditated under some 2500 years ago. Together with the temple of the tooth in Kandy these are the two most sacred places on the island.
Very interesting shrine, well worth a visit if you are in the area
A real hive of activity. Unlike many temple areas which are often deserted, this was full of people, both devotees and tourists. We went in the evening but it may be just as busy all day.

The temple was busy with pilgrims so you needn't take your round ticket to this place. Quite interesting to watch devotees chanting and walking around, making offerings of fruits, etc but the Sacred Bo tree was barely visible so just be aware of that. A couple of scammers tried to get us to pay Rs200 for a piece of cotton which was wrapped around my partner's wrist without asking first.  then someone else tried to sell me some rare coins or something. It was a bit hassly.  Ok if you are a buddhist or are into temple-watching but not worth going out of your way to see otherwise. Good for photos, with all the flags hanging from various Bo trees in the temple complex.  Imagine what the buddha would make of all this deification!
i liked the old architecture and ruins. well kept.

This is a key part of a visit to the sacred city. As a visual attraction it is a little underwhelming (its a tree partially hidden from sight) but if you're looking to understand some of the Sri Lankan religious culture then understanding its purpose and watching those worshipping here is a must. Visiting the site involves a short walk without wearing a hat. Its a good idea to have an umbrella with you to avoid heat stroke.

We left our shoes far before the temple. Unfortunately we were in the Temple with Bo tree 5 minutes before the doors were closed for preach.. We had time only for a glimpe of the tree and it was difficult to go out of the temple. The area was crowded. Nevertheless we had to pay the entrance fee of more than 10 US dollars. There were too many people coming there for a celebration of the temple. They brought flowers. The place were full with monkeys. Interesting place but we had no time to enjoy the place
This is the real bodhi tree that a sapling was brought from India, it is over 2000 years old and one of the oldest trees on earth. A great and blessed place

I visited the Bo Tree in the evening during the puja time and was amazed with the energy around. It was a humbling experience. The place has many Buddha statues in different positions scatter all around the holy Bo. There are prayer flags all around and can see people add more to the collection. The evening I had been here there was a special prayer service for all the families who had lost their loved ones in war. The atmosphere was emotionally charged. I was just glad to have been able to be a part of it. Definitely an experience I will remember!

Don't often get the chance to see the oldest and probably the most sacred tree in existence. Couldn't help but marvel at the tree and the devotees gathered around. Tree surrounded by tourists and pilgrims alike. Loved the chanting and the ceremony going on.

Based on what we had read, we were looking forward to our visit to the Bo Tree. It is said that the Tree has grown from a Branch for the original tree at which Lord Budhha meditated. One of the locals also pointed out the differences between the Sacred Bo Tree and other trees of the same variety found elsewhere. Meticulous care is now being taaken to preserve it. The approach to the tree is around 200 meters and monks live in proximity to the Tree Complex. It is one of the holiest Buddhist shrines in the world. At the same time the area has been elegently maintained and there is nothing ornate. As usual. please carry your own bottle of water as there are no shops nearby and the toilets  need to be avoided.
This said to be the branch of the tree that gave shade to lord Buddha when he was meditating .the place very crowded during poya days and on month of may. Other than that the it’s very peaceful
We were lucky enough to see this place on a Sunday night when all the locals go there offering flowers and praying. It was a very authentic experience.

Sri Lanka's economy has collapsed and everyone is on the make to fleece any tourist stepping foot in the island - Buddhist clergy included. The Bo tree site could be magic but isn't. One 'fleecing' might be no issue but everywhere? Government run guesthouses (chicken neck for your high priced evening meal), this year's price hike for Kandy Temple of the Tooth and again for Anuradhapura - heavy for a family of four. Special rates for tourists are imposed everywhere with real agression. Sometimes demanded at army checkpoints! Avoid the place - Thailand's much better.

The oldest sacred tree in Sri Lanka, and possibly the world, visitors can only get a glimpse of this tree. The tree is off-limits to all visitors, and as it is fronted by a formalised entrance with high walls, you can only see the upper branches of it. It maybe historical and a place of religious importance, but for me it didn't live up to expectations. I wouldn't like to discourage others  visiting it, but I wouldn't recommend it to friends or family.
